children.name: Erythema multiforme-like rash
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical steroids, systemic steroids for severe cases.

children.name: Maculopapular Rash
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical steroids, antihistamines. Similar to PI3K inhibitor rash management.

children.name: Stomatitis / mIAS
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Alcohol-free Dexamethasone mouthwash (0.5 mg/5 mL) swish and spit 4 times daily. Management: Grade 1: Non-alcoholic mouthwash, salt water. Grade 2: Topical steroids (Triamcinolone), topical anesthetics. Hold drug. Grade 3: Interrupt drug until Grade ≤1, then restart at reduced dose. Avoid alcohol/hydrogen peroxide mouthwashes.

children.name: Acneiform Rash (Acneiform eruption)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Hypoallergenic moisturizers, tepid showers. Management: Grade 1: Moisturizers, topical steroids, topical antibiotics (Clindamycin). Grade 2: Oral antihistamines, mid-potency topical steroids. Grade 3: Interruption or dose reduction, systemic steroids.

children.name: Alopecia
children.management_prevention: Usually nonscarring and reversible. Management: Wigs (Grade 1), Minoxidil (may help shorten duration), topical steroids (non-scarring).

children.name: Hand-Foot Syndrome (HFSR, Hyperkeratotic plaques)
children.incidence: 34% (Sorafenib) High prevalence of hyperkeratosis in BRAFi
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Comfortable shoes, thick cotton socks, remove calluses beforehand. Management: Grade 1: Keratolytics (Urea 10-40%, Salicylic acid) and moisturizers. Grade 2+: Potent topical steroids (Clobetasol), topical anesthetics (Lidocaine), analgesics (NSAIDs, GABA agonists). Severe: Interrupt drug.

children.name: Keratinizing Skin Tumors (cuSCC, Keratoacanthoma, Papilloma)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Regular full-body skin exam (every 4-8 weeks), Strict sun protection. Management: Surgical excision (standard) or shave removal. No need to stop/reduce drug. Local/Systemic therapy (5-FU, Imiquimod, Acitretin) for multiple lesions.

children.name: Panniculitis
children.management_prevention: Management: Rest, leg elevation, NSAIDs, systemic steroids. Usually resolves without stopping the drug.

children.name: Photosensitivity
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Strict sun protection (UVA block, SPF 30+, PA+++), protective clothing (long sleeves, hats). Caution with window glass. Management: Topical steroids, cold compress, NSAIDs. Grade 2+: Consider dose reduction or interruption.

children.name: Rash maculo-papular (Maculopapular rash)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Hypoallergenic moisturizers, tepid showers. Management: Grade 1: Moisturizers, topical steroids (Hydrocortisone, Triamcinolone), topical antibiotics. Grade 2: Oral antihistamines, mid-potency topical steroids. Grade 3: Interruption or dose reduction, systemic steroids (Prednisolone 0.5mg/kg).

children.name: Acneiform Rash (Acneiform/papulopustular rash)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Pre-emptive oral tetracyclines (Minocycline/Doxycycline 100mg), topical steroids (Hydrocortisone 1%), moisturizers, sun protection. Management: Grade 1: Topical steroids (Hydrocortisone, Alclometasone), topical antibiotics (Clindamycin, Metronidazole). Grade 2: Oral antibiotics (Doxycycline/Minocycline 100mg). Grade 3: Hold/reduce dose; Oral antibiotics + short-term oral corticosteroids (Prednisolone 0.5 mg/kg); Low-dose Isotretinoin for refractory cases.
children.drug_examples_raw: mAbs: Cetuximab, Panitumumab, Necitumumab, Nimotuzumab, Matuzumab, Zalutumumab TKIs: Gefitinib, Erlotinib, Lapatinib, Afatinib, Dacomitinib, Neratinib, Osimertinib, Icotinib, Mobocertinib, Poziotinib

children.name: Alopecia (Mild, Androgenetic pattern)
children.management_prevention: Management: Wigs (Grade 1), Topical Minoxidil (may help shorten duration), topical steroids (non-scarring).
children.drug_examples_raw: mAbs: Cetuximab, Panitumumab, Necitumumab, Nimotuzumab, Matuzumab, Zalutumumab TKIs: Gefitinib, Erlotinib, Lapatinib, Afatinib, Dacomitinib, Neratinib, Osimertinib, Icotinib, Mobocertinib, Poziotinib

children.name: Dry skin (Xerosis) and Fissures
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Avoid irritants (alcohol, perfume), use tepid water, moisturizers BID. Management: Xerosis: Moisturizers with Urea/Lactic acid/Salicylic acid; Topical steroids (Grade 3). Fissures: Liquid bandage (Cyanoacrylate), hydrocolloid dressing, Zinc oxide, topical antibiotics, Lidocaine.
children.drug_examples_raw: mAbs: Cetuximab, Panitumumab, Necitumumab, Nimotuzumab, Matuzumab, Zalutumumab TKIs: Gefitinib, Erlotinib, Lapatinib, Afatinib, Dacomitinib, Neratinib, Osimertinib, Icotinib, Mobocertinib, Poziotinib

children.name: Hair color changes (Poliosis)
children.management_prevention: Management: Cosmetic camouflage (Wigs, etc.) if associated with hair loss.
children.drug_examples_raw: mAbs: Cetuximab, Panitumumab, Necitumumab, Nimotuzumab, Matuzumab, Zalutumumab TKIs: Gefitinib, Erlotinib, Lapatinib, Afatinib, Dacomitinib, Neratinib, Osimertinib, Icotinib, Mobocertinib, Poziotinib

children.name: Hair texture abnormal (Brittle, kinky, curly hair, slower growth)
children.management_prevention: Management: Wigs (if alopecia occurs), topical Minoxidil or steroids for associated hair loss.
children.drug_examples_raw: mAbs: Cetuximab, Panitumumab, Necitumumab, Nimotuzumab, Matuzumab, Zalutumumab TKIs: Gefitinib, Erlotinib, Lapatinib, Afatinib, Dacomitinib, Neratinib, Osimertinib, Icotinib, Mobocertinib, Poziotinib

children.name: Hirsutism (Unwanted hair growth in women)
children.management_prevention: Management: Depilatory creams, laser hair removal, Eflornithine cream.
children.drug_examples_raw: mAbs: Cetuximab, Panitumumab, Necitumumab, Nimotuzumab, Matuzumab, Zalutumumab TKIs: Gefitinib, Erlotinib, Lapatinib, Afatinib, Dacomitinib, Neratinib, Osimertinib, Icotinib, Mobocertinib, Poziotinib

children.name: Hypertrichosis (Trichomegaly of eyelashes)
children.management_prevention: Management: Trichomegaly: Regular trimming to prevent corneal damage/keratitis. Ophthalmology consultation if severe.
children.drug_examples_raw: mAbs: Cetuximab, Panitumumab, Necitumumab, Nimotuzumab, Matuzumab, Zalutumumab TKIs: Gefitinib, Erlotinib, Lapatinib, Afatinib, Dacomitinib, Neratinib, Osimertinib, Icotinib, Mobocertinib, Poziotinib

children.name: Oral Mucositis / Stomatitis
children.management_prevention: Management: Oral hygiene (soft toothbrush), avoid irritants. Topical steroids (Triamcinolone), Lidocaine, antibiotic gargle.
children.drug_examples_raw: mAbs: Cetuximab, Panitumumab, Necitumumab, Nimotuzumab, Matuzumab, Zalutumumab TKIs: Gefitinib, Erlotinib, Lapatinib, Afatinib, Dacomitinib, Neratinib, Osimertinib, Icotinib, Mobocertinib, Poziotinib

children.name: Periungual / Nail Fold Toxicity (Paronychia, Pyogenic granuloma)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Avoid trauma/cutting nails too short, vinegar or chloramine soaks, prophylactic Doxycycline. Management: Grade 1: Topical potent steroids (Clobetasol) or antibiotics (Mupirocin), antiseptic soaks. Grade 2: Silver nitrate cauterization, oral antibiotics, topical beta-blockers (Timolol/Betaxolol). Grade 3: Partial nail avulsion.
children.drug_examples_raw: mAbs: Cetuximab, Panitumumab, Necitumumab, Nimotuzumab, Matuzumab, Zalutumumab TKIs: Gefitinib, Erlotinib, Lapatinib, Afatinib, Dacomitinib, Neratinib, Osimertinib, Icotinib, Mobocertinib, Poziotinib

children.name: Pruritus
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Moisturizing, tepid water. Management: Grade 1: Topical steroids, Menthol, Pramoxine. Grade 2: Oral antihistamines (non-sedating/sedating) + topical steroids. Grade 3: GABA agonists (Gabapentin/Pregabalin), Aprepitant (NK-1 antagonist), short-term oral Prednisone.

children.name: Acneiform/papulopustular eruption (No comedones)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Hypoallergenic cleansers/moisturizers, sun protection. Consider pre-emptive oral antibiotics (Minocycline or Doxycycline). Management: Grade 1-2: Topical steroids (Class 3-4), topical antibiotics (Clindamycin), oral antihistamines for pruritus. Grade 3: Interrupt/reduce dose, oral antibiotics (Tetracycline), short-term systemic steroids (Prednisone 0.5-1 mg/kg). Culture to rule out infection.

children.name: Alopecia
children.management_prevention: Management: Wigs (Grade 1), Topical Minoxidil (may help shorten duration), topical steroids (non-scarring).

children.name: Dry skin (Xerosis)
children.tti: Within 6 months (Can be slow or persistent)
children.management_prevention: Management: Apply emollients (moisturizers) BID or more. Urea-containing creams may help.

children.name: Eczematous dermatitis
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical steroids for inflammatory lesions. Antihistamines or GABA agonists for severe pruritus.

children.name: Edema (Peripheral edema, Periorbital/Facial edema)
children.management_prevention: Management: Compression therapy, leg elevation. Diuretics or dose adjustment for severe cases.

children.name: Hair texture abnormal
children.management_prevention: Management: Regular trimming

children.name: Oral Mucositis / Stomatitis
children.management_prevention: Management: Oral hygiene maintenance. Topical steroid gargle/application. Local anesthetics for pain.

children.name: Paronychia (Periungual inflammation)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Comfortable shoes, do not cut nails too short, avoid cuticle removal. Vinegar or diluted bleach soaks. Management: Mild: Potent topical steroids (Clobetasol), topical antibiotics (Mupirocin), antiseptic/warm saline soaks. Moderate+: Oral antibiotics (Doxycycline). Silver nitrate or surgery for granuloma.

children.name: Skin hypopigmentation (Pigmentary dilution)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Photoprotection. Management: Topcial steroid

children.name: Acneiform Rash
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical steroids, antibiotics.

children.name: Dry skin (Xerosis)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Start emollients at the beginning of therapy. Management: Apply thick moisturizers frequently. Use creams containing Urea 10-40% or Ammonium lactate 12% for severe cases.

children.name: Eczematous dermatitis (Eczematoid rash)
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical steroids, moisturizers.

children.name: Hand-Foot Skin Reaction (HFSR)
children.management_prevention: Management: Moisturizers, keratolytics, topical steroids.

children.name: Nail changes (Brittle nails)
children.management_prevention: Management: Protective measures, moisturizers.

children.name: Nail loss (Onycholysis)
children.management_prevention: Management: Keep nails short, avoid trauma.

children.name: Paronychia (Periungual inflammation)
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical antibiotic ointment, topical steroids, vinegar soaks. Treat similarly to EGFR inhibitor toxicity.

children.name: Pruritus
children.management_prevention: Management: Moisturizers, Oral antihistamines, Topical steroids.

children.name: Pyogenic granuloma (Granuloma-like lesions)
children.management_prevention: Management: Silver nitrate, surgical intervention if necessary.

children.name: Rash maculo-papular (Morbilliform rash)
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical steroids, antihistamines.

children.name: Stomatitis / mIAS (Aphthous-like ulcers)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Alcohol-free Dexamethasone mouthwash (0.5 mg/5 mL) swish and spit 4 times daily. Management: Grade 1: Non-alcoholic mouthwash, salt water. Grade 2: Topical steroids (Triamcinolone), topical anesthetics. Hold drug. Grade 3: Interrupt drug until Grade ≤1, then restart at reduced dose. Avoid alcohol/hydrogen peroxide mouthwashes.

children.name: Acneiform Rash
children.management_prevention: Management: Similar to general rash management (Topical steroids, etc.).
children.drug_examples_raw: Sorafenib, Sunitinib, Pazopanib, Regorafenib, Cabozantinib, Vandetanib, Lenvatinib, Axitinib

children.name: Alopecia
children.management_prevention: Management: Wigs (Grade 1), Topical Minoxidil (may help shorten duration), topical steroids (non-scarring).

children.name: Hair color changes (Depigmentation, Yellowing)
children.management_prevention: Management: No treatment required. Reversible.

children.name: Hand-Foot Skin Reaction (HFSR) (Hyperkeratotic plaques, callus, blistering)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Remove calluses before treatment. Wear comfortable shoes with insoles and thick cotton socks. Prophylactic Urea 10% cream. Management: Grade 1: Moisturizers, Keratolytics (Urea 20-40%, Salicylic acid 6%), Cushioning. Grade 2: Potent topical steroids (Clobetasol 0.05%), Topical anesthetics (Lidocaine 2-5%). Grade 3: Interrupt drug (min. 7 days). Oral analgesics (NSAIDs, GABA agonists, Opioids).
children.drug_examples_raw: Sorafenib, Sunitinib, Regorafenib, Cabozantinib, Pazopanib, Vandetanib, Lenvatinib, Axitinib

children.name: Keratinizing Skin Tumors (cuSCC, Keratoacanthoma)
children.management_prevention: Management: Surgical excision or cryotherapy. Drug interruption is not required.

children.name: Maculopapular Rash
children.management_prevention: Management: Use moisturizers and mild cleansers. Grade 1-2: Topical steroids (Class 3-4), Oral antihistamines. Grade 3: Interrupt drug, Short-term systemic steroids.
children.drug_examples_raw: Sunitinib (Common), Sorafenib, Pazopanib, Regorafenib, Cabozantinib, Vandetanib, Lenvatinib, Axitinib

children.name: Oral Mucositis / Stomatitis
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Oral hygiene maintenance. Management: Topical steroid gargle/application. Local anesthetics(Lidoc for pain.

children.name: Scrotal erythema and ulceration
children.management_prevention: Management: Dose modification or temporary hold. Topical management(prevention of infection, promote wound healing)

children.name: Seborrheic dermatitis-like eruption (Facial and scalp erythema/scale)
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical antifungals (Ketoconazole), Mild topical steroids.

children.name: Skin Hypopigmentation / Depigmentation
children.tti: Early onset (Sunitinib: might be within one week)
children.management_prevention: Management: No treatment required. Educate patient that it is reversible upon discontinuation.

children.name: Subungual splinter hemorrhages
children.management_prevention: Management: No treatment required if painless. Resolves naturally.

children.name: Yellow discoloration of skin
children.management_prevention: Management: No treatment required. Due to drug metabolite color. Reversible.

children.name: Dry skin (Xerosis)
children.management_prevention: Management: Moisturizers, Urea creams. Note: Hyperglycemia (Alpelisib) can exacerbate dry skin.

children.name: Maculopapular Rash (Rash maculo-papular)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Prophylactic non-sedating antihistamines (e.g., Cetirizine 10mg) recommended. Management: Grade 1: Topical steroids, moisturizers. Grade 2: Topical steroids, oral prednisone (0.5-1 mg/kg). Grade 3: Hold drug, systemic steroids (Prednisone 0.5-1 mg/kg) for 10-14 days. Restart at reduced dose upon improvement.

children.name: Pruritus
children.management_prevention: Management: Moisturizers, Oral antihistamines.

children.name: Stomatitis / mIAS
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Alcohol-free Dexamethasone mouthwash (0.5 mg/5 mL) swish and spit 4 times daily. Management: Grade 1: Non-alcoholic mouthwash, salt water. Grade 2: Topical steroids (Triamcinolone), topical anesthetics. Hold drug. Grade 3: Interrupt drug until Grade ≤1, then restart at reduced dose. Avoid alcohol/hydrogen peroxide mouthwashes.
children.drug_examples_raw: Alpelisib (Common), Copanlisib, Idelalisib, Duvelisib, Umbralisib, Inavolisib

children.name: Alopecia
children.management_prevention: Management: Wigs (Grade 1), Topical Minoxidil (may help shorten duration), topical steroids (non-scarring).

children.name: Autoimmune Bullous Dermatoses (Bullous pemphigoid)
children.management_prevention: Diagnosis: Skin biopsy (DIF), BP180/BP230 antibodies. Management: Mild: Potent topical steroids. Moderate+: Stop ICI, Systemic steroids (0.5-2 mg/kg). Refractory: Rituximab, Omalizumab, Dapsone, Methotrexate.

children.name: Dermatomyositis
children.management_prevention: Management: High-dose IV Methylprednisolone (1–2 mg/kg/day or pulse therapy), Oral Prednisone (1 mg/kg/day). Refractory: IVIG, Plasmapheresis, or other immunosuppressants (Methotrexate, Azathioprine, Mycophenolate Mofetil)

children.name: DRESS Syndrome
children.management_prevention: Management: Similar to SJS/TEN (Systemic steroids, supportive care).

children.name: Lichenoid eruption (Lichenoid dermatitis)
children.management_prevention: Management: First-line: Potent topical steroids (Clobetasol). Refractory/Widespread: Oral steroids or NB-UVB phototherapy. Steroid-sparing agents: Acitretin, Methotrexate, Hydroxychloroquine.

children.name: Maculopapular rash (Morbilliform)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Hypoallergenic moisturizers BID, tepid showers, sun protection. Management: Grade 1 (<10% BSA): Continue ICI. Topical steroids (mid-high potency), oral antihistamines, moisturizers. Grade 2 (10-30% BSA): Consider holding ICI. High potency topical steroids, oral antihistamines. Systemic steroids (Prednisone 0.5-1 mg/kg) if persistent. Grade 3 (>30% BSA): Hold ICI. Systemic steroids (Prednisone 1-2 mg/kg), taper over 4-6 weeks. Grade 4: Permanently discontinue ICI. IV Methylprednisolone 1-2 mg/kg. Admit to burn unit.

children.name: Oral Mucositis
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical steroid gargle (Dexamethasone), Ointment, Lidocaine solution. Systemic steroids if severe.

children.name: Pruritus
children.management_prevention: Management: Grade 1-2: Topical steroids, Menthol, Pramoxine, Oral antihistamines (Cetirizine, Hydroxyzine). Grade 3 (Severe/Refractory): GABA agonists (Gabapentin, Pregabalin), NK-1 receptor antagonists (Aprepitant). Biologics like Dupilumab or Omalizumab reported effective for refractory cases.
children.drug_examples_raw: Ipilimumab, Tremelimumab (More common CTLA-4 > PD-1/PD-L1); Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab, etc.

children.name: Psoriasis / Psoriasiform
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical steroids, Vitamin D analogs. Severe: Acitretin, Methotrexate, Apremilast. Caution with biologics (IL-17/IL-23 inhibitors).

children.name: Scleroderma
children.management_prevention: Management: Hold ICI, Prednisone 0.5–1 mg/kg/day. DMARDs (Methotrexate, Anti-TNF- α, IL-6 antagonists) may be considered for refractory arthritis, which often co-occurs

children.name: SJS / TEN (Stevens-Johnson syndrome / Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis)
children.management_prevention: Management: Permanent discontinuation of ICI. ICU admission. High-dose IV steroids (Methylprednisolone 1-2 mg/kg/day). IVIG, Cyclosporine, Infliximab if steroid-refractory.

children.name: Vitiligo-like depigmentation (Vitiligo)
children.management_prevention: Management: Usually no treatment required (continue ICI). Educate on sun protection (burn prevention). Topical steroids or calcineurin inhibitors have limited effect. Considered a positive prognostic factor.

children.name: Acneiform Rash
children.management_prevention: Management: Not specified.

children.name: Acute Generalized Exanthematous Pustulosis (AGEP)
children.management_prevention: Management: Not specified.

children.name: Alopecia (Anagen effluvium)
children.incidence: Estimated overall incidence: 65%. High risk: Taxanes (>80%), Anthracyclines (60–100%)
children.tti: Usually occurs within 7–10 days. Typically within 2–4 weeks
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Scalp cooling (effective for Taxanes/Anthracyclines). Management: Wigs, sun protection. Minoxidil may help hair regrowth speed after treatment. Topical steroids if inflammation exists on biopsy.
children.drug_examples_raw: Taxanes: Paclitaxel, Docetaxel Anthracyclines: Doxorubicin Alkylating: Cyclophosphamide, Ifosfamide

children.name: Dry skin (Xerosis, Scaling)
children.tti: Epidermal barrier damage occurs early in treatment
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Emoilients Management: Bland emollients (Moisturizers).
children.drug_examples_raw: Taxanes: Docetaxel, Paclitaxel Alkylating: Estramustine, Temozolomide

children.name: Edema (Peripheral pitting edema)
children.tti: Docetaxel: onset related to cumulative dose (>400 mg/m2 or 4th–5th cycle)
children.management_prevention: Management: Premedication with steroids. Diuretics/Compression/Physical therapy. Dose modification/interruption

children.name: Erythema (Intertriginous/Flexural eruption)
children.incidence: Liposomal Doxorubicin: can cause intertrigo-like rash (8% incidence). Docetaxel: can cause inflammatory patches in flexural areas
children.management_prevention: Management: Low-potency topical corticosteroids (for mild cases). Topical antifungals/azoles (if fungal infection suspected)
children.drug_examples_raw: Taxanes (Intertriginous eruption), Pegylated Liposomal Doxorubicin (Intertrigo-like rash)

children.name: Erythema multiforme
children.management_prevention: Management: Stop offending agent. Systemic corticosteroids and IVIG use is controversial

children.name: Folliculitis (Sterile)
children.management_prevention: Management: Not specified (Noted as sterile).

children.name: Hand-Foot Syndrome (HFS) (Palmar-Plantar Erythrodysesthesia)
children.tti: Typically within 1 day to several weeks after starting CTX
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Celecoxib (proven in RCT for Capecitabine), Urea 10% cream, Cooling (for Pegylated Liposomal Doxorubicin or Docetaxel). Pyridoxine is not recommended. Management: Cold compress, moisturizers, potent topical steroids, analgesics. Grade 2-3: Dose reduction or interruption.
children.drug_examples_raw: Capecitabine (Most common), Doxorubicin, 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU), Cytarabine, Taxanes (Docetaxel > Paclitaxel), Methotrexate

children.name: Inflammation of Actinic Keratoses
children.incidence: Fluorouracil, Docetaxel, Doxorubicin, Cytarabine, Paclitaxel: associated
children.tti: Develops in the first week of chemotherapy
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical corticosteroids

children.name: Nail changes (Onycholysis, Onychomadesis, Subungual abscess)
children.tti: Nail changes are evident after several weeks of treatment. Onycholysis/Abscess: may begin within a few weeks
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Frozen gloves/socks (Cooling). Management: Keep nails short, avoid trauma. Soaking in diluted vinegar (1:1 or 1:10) for onycholysis. Saline soaking, Topical steroids/antibiotics for inflammation/infection.

children.name: Nail discoloration (Diffuse or banded hyperpigmentation, Melanonychia)
children.incidence: Cyclophosphamide, Doxorubicin, Hydroxyurea: commonly induce pigmentation
children.tti: Melanonychia: develops after several months of therapy
children.management_prevention: Management: Camouflage with nail polish

children.name: Oral Mucositis / Stomatitis
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Oral cryotherapy (Ice chips) for 5-FU. Management: Dexamethasone mouthwash, supportive care(lidocaine, etc)
children.drug_examples_raw: 5-FU, Melphalan, Cisplatin (90% with RT), Docetaxel, Bendamustine, Ifosfamide, Bleomycin, Doxorubicin

children.name: Paronychia (Periungual inflammation)
children.tti: Develops after several weeks or months of treatment
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical steroids, antibiotic ointment. Severe cases: Surgical drainage.

children.name: Persistent Alopecia (CIPAL)
children.incidence: Permanent loss ≥ 6 months post-cessation. Higher risk: Docetaxel (2% incidence reported), Busulfan
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical Minoxidil (up to 5%): may potentially stimulate regrowth. Surgical (hair transplantation)
children.drug_examples_raw: Taxanes: Docetaxel, Paclitaxel Alkylating: Busulfan (High dose)

children.name: Photosensitivity (Phototoxicity)
children.incidence: Fluorouracil, Capecitabine, Dacarbazine, Vinblastine: involved. Paclitaxel, Docetaxel: cause UV recall
children.tti: Sunburn-like reactions: within minutes to weeks/months
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Strict sun protection (Sunscreen, protective clothing). Management: Cessation of causing agents, Topical/Systemic steroids, NSAIDs, antihistamines.

children.name: Pruritus
children.management_prevention: Prevention: moisturization/skin care Management: antihistsamines, topical antipruritics

children.name: Radiation Recall Dermatitis
children.incidence: Doxorubicin, Capecitabine, Gemcitabine, Docetaxel, Paclitaxel: involved
children.tti: During, immediately after, or within days of chemo
children.management_prevention: Management: Cessation/delay, Topical, systemic corticosteroids.
children.drug_examples_raw: Taxanes, Doxorubicin, Gemcitabine, Methotrexate, Cisplatin, Dactinomycin

children.name: Rash maculo-papular (Diffuse macules and papules, Morbilliform eruption)
children.incidence: Cladribine, Gemcitabine, Fludarabine: reported. Gemcitabine: reported in 19%
children.tti: Gemcitabine (Etoposide similar): begins about 1 week after initiation
children.management_prevention: Management: Topical steroids or systemic corticosteroids Severe cases: Dose reduction or interruption.
children.drug_examples_raw: Taxanes: Docetaxel (Very common), Paclitaxel Alkylating: Temozolomide, Estramustine

children.name: Skin hyperpigmentation (Flagellate dermatitis, Serpentine supravenous hyperpigmentation)
children.incidence: Bleomycin (Flagellate dermatitis): up to 30%. Taxanes (Serpentine): reported
children.tti: Bleomycin (Flagellate): onset is hours to months after infusion
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Strict sun avoidance Management: Flagellate Dermatitis: resolves 3–4 months post-cessation. Topical retinoids (for improved melanin turnover)

children.name: Skin ulceration (Extravasation / Tissue necrosis)
children.incidence: Anthracyclines (Doxorubicin), Vinca alkaloids (Vincristine), Taxanes (Paclitaxel, Docetaxel): primary vesicants
children.tti: Onset is subclinical initially (burning, erythema) followed by necrosis after 2–3 days
children.management_prevention: Management: Stop infusion immediately, aspirate drug. Cold pack: Anthracyclines, Taxanes, Alkylating agents. Warm pack: Vinca Alkaloids, Etoposide. Antidotes: Dexrazoxane/DMSO (Anthracyclines), Hyaluronidase (Vinca Alkaloids).
children.drug_examples_raw: Anthracyclines: Doxorubicin Vinca Alkaloids: Vincristine, Vinblastine Mitotic: Taxanes

children.name: Stiff skin (Scleroderma-like changes, Cutaneous sclerosis/fibrosis)
children.incidence: Paclitaxel/Docetaxel: cause cutaneous sclerosis. Bleomycin: cause localized sclerosis.
children.management_prevention: Management: Resolves upon drug discontinuation. Prednisone +(Methotexate)

children.name: Urticaria (Hypersensitivity reaction)
children.incidence: Platinum drugs, Taxanes, Cyclophosphamide: common offenders
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Pretreatment with steroids/antihistamines. Desensitization protocols Management: Antihistamines and corticosteroids

children.name: UV Recall Reaction (Inflammation on previous solar erythema)
children.incidence: Paclitaxel, Docetaxel: causative agents. Methotrexate also implicated
children.tti: Days or weeks after chemo (on old burn site)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Sun avoidance Management: Removal of offending agent (chemotherapy). Topical/Systemic Corticosteroids (for symptomatic relief)

children.name: Acneiform Rash
children.management_prevention: Management: Similar to general rash management.

children.name: Alopecia
children.incidence: Sacituzumab govitecan (SG): 46~50% (All Grades), Trastuzumab deruxtecan (T-DXd): 37% (All Grades), Datopotamab deruxtecan (Dato-DXd): 65% (All Grades)
children.tti: Not specified (Generally, several months after initiation)
children.management_prevention: Management: Wigs, supportive care. Scalp cooling may be effective for T-DXd (evidence accumulating).
children.drug_examples_raw: Sacituzumab govitecan (SG), Trastuzumab deruxtecan (T-DXd), Datopotamab deruxtecan (Dato-DXd)

children.name: Dermatosis bullous (Bullous lesions)
children.incidence: Not specified (Part of severe ADC toxicity)
children.tti: Not specified (Within the first cycle of treatment for EV)
children.management_prevention: Management: Immediate interruption (Hold). If severe, permanently discontinue. Systemic steroids. Rule out SJS/TEN.

children.name: DRESS Syndrome
children.incidence: Not specified (Rare, Case Reports with Brentuximab vedotin, Enfortumab vedotin, etc.)
children.management_prevention: Management: Immediate discontinuation. Systemic steroids.

children.name: Dry skin (Xerosis)
children.management_prevention: Management: Moisturizers.

children.name: Erythema (SDRIFE-like rash in intertriginous areas)
children.tti: Within days to several weeks after initiation (EV standard)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Zinc-containing moisturizers on intertriginous areas. Management: Topical steroids, moisturizers.

children.name: Erythroderma (Exfoliative dermatitis)
children.incidence: Not specified (Part of EV Grade ≥3 toxicity)
children.tti: Within the first cycle of treatment (EV standard)
children.management_prevention: Management: Treat as severe skin reaction (Grade 3). Stop drug and administer systemic steroids.

children.name: Hand-Foot Syndrome (HFS) (PPE)
children.tti: Within days to several weeks after initiation (EV standard)
children.management_prevention: Management: Standard HFS management (Moisturizers, Urea).

children.name: Lichenoid dermatitis (Lichenoid rash)
children.management_prevention: Management: Grade 1-2: Topical corticosteroids (TCS) (topical intervention indicated),,; Severe (Grade ≥ 3): Hold ADC/ICI therapy, initiate high-dose systemic corticosteroids

children.name: Maculopapular Rash (Rash, Maculopapular rash)
children.tti: EV: Within 1 month (1st cycle); General: Within weeks
children.management_prevention: Prevention: EV: Apply Zinc-containing moisturizers to intertriginous areas. Sunscreen. Management: Grade 1: Moisturizers, topical steroids, oral antihistamines. Grade 2: Potent topical steroids. Hold drug until improved to Grade ≤1. Grade 3: Permanently discontinue EV (for severe/bullous). Systemic steroids (Prednisone 0.5-1 mg/kg).
children.drug_examples_raw: Enfortumab vedotin (EV), Sacituzumab govitecan (SG), Brentuximab vedotin (BV), Loncastuximab tesirine (LT), General ADCs

children.name: Oral Mucositis / Stomatitis
children.tti: Not specified (Generally, within 8 weeks after initiation)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Dexamethasone mouthwash gargle. Management: Soft toothbrush, avoid irritants. Topical anesthetics/coating agents.
children.drug_examples_raw: Sacituzumab govitecan (SG), Trastuzumab deruxtecan (T-DXd), Datopotamab deruxtecan (Dato-DXd)

children.name: Photosensitivity (Phototoxic rash)
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Minimize sun exposure. Wear sun-protective clothing (essential due to PBD payload). Sunscreen. Management: Steroids have limited effect.

children.name: Pruritus
children.management_prevention: Management: Oral antihistamines, moisturizers.

children.name: Skin hyperpigmentation
children.management_prevention: Prevention: Strict sun avoidance with broad spectrum UV protection. Management: Camouflage discoloration, topical retinoids, hydroquinone

children.name: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)
children.incidence: Not specified (Rare, reported as SCAR in ADCs)
children.management_prevention: Management: Permanently discontinue drug immediately. Hospitalization, high-dose systemic steroids (Methylprednisolone), supportive care.

children.name: Telangiectasia (Spider angioma-like, Diffuse reticulated)
children.management_prevention: Management: T-DM1: Laser therapy or Electrocautery for persistent lesions (cosmetic/psychological benefit).

children.name: Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN)
children.incidence: Not specified (Rare, reported as SCAR in ADCs)
children.management_prevention: Management: Same as SJS. Permanently discontinue.
